articles.headline: North Korea Rails Against New Sanctions. Whether They Will Work Is Unclear.
articles.snippet: North Korea threatened retaliation “thousands of times” for the most punishing sanctions yet. But history suggests North Korea will devise workarounds.
articles.abstract: North Korea threatened retaliation “thousands of times” for the most punishing sanctions yet. But history suggests North Korea will devise workarounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has hailed the latest United Nations sanctions against nuclear-armed North Korea as the most severe yet, and the North’s fury over the penalties suggested they carried some sting.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Despite S.E.C. Warning, Wave of Initial Coin Offerings Grows
articles.snippet: Several coming coin offerings have hired lawyers to try to play by the rules. Others prohibit Americans from investing.
articles.abstract: Several coming coin offerings have hired lawyers to try to play by the rules. Others prohibit Americans from investing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The cautionary words of American regulators have done little to chill a red-hot market for new virtual currencies sold by start-ups.

articles.headline: Trump Likes When C.I.A. Chief Gets Political, but Officers Are Wary
articles.snippet: Mike Pompeo has become a favorite of the president’s with tough talk and hawkish views at the helm of the C.I.A., which prides itself on being apolitical.
articles.abstract: Mike Pompeo has become a favorite of the president’s with tough talk and hawkish views at the helm of the C.I.A., which prides itself on being apolitical.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — Sweating under the hot glare of stage lights, Mike Pompeo, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, had reached the limits of his patience with questions about Russian interference in the presidential election.

articles.headline: As Stocks Reach New Heights, What’s Trump Got to Do With It?
articles.snippet: Sizzling corporate earnings reports, not the president’s deregulatory agenda, are fueling the bull market.
articles.abstract: Sizzling corporate earnings reports, not the president’s deregulatory agenda, are fueling the bull market.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Business is looking better than ever with business enthusiasm at record levels. Stock Market at an all-time high. That doesn’t just happen!”

articles.headline: Wells Fargo, Awash in Scandal, Faces Violations Over Car Insurance Refunds
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco is investigating the lender for not refunding car buyers who bought special insurance and repaid their loans early.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco is investigating the lender for not refunding car buyers who bought special insurance and repaid their loans early.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo, the scandal-plagued bank, is facing new regulatory scrutiny for not refunding insurance money owed to people who paid off their car loans early, according to people briefed on the inquiry.

articles.headline: Trump Threatens ‘Fire and Fury’ Against North Korea if It Endangers U.S.
articles.snippet: North Korea hinted that it would conduct another nuclear or missile test, as it has often done in response to past United Nations sanctions.
articles.abstract: North Korea hinted that it would conduct another nuclear or missile test, as it has often done in response to past United Nations sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIDGEWATER, N.J. — President Trump threatened on Tuesday to unleash “fire and fury” against North Korea if it endangered the United States, as tensions with the isolated and impoverished nuclear-armed state escalated into perhaps the most serious foreign policy challenge yet of his administration.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: As Maduro’s Venezuela Rips Apart, So Does His Military
articles.snippet: President Nicolás Maduro has taken great pains to reward military leaders for loyalty, but some in the rank and file are turning against him.
articles.abstract: President Nicolás Maduro has taken great pains to reward military leaders for loyalty, but some in the rank and file are turning against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Fugitive Venezuelan soldiers have declared a rebellion against “the murderous tyranny” of the president. Dissident officers have fled the country, seeking asylum. Grenades have been fired at the Supreme Court and, this weekend, assailants under the command of a mutinous captain attacked an army base, making off with weapons.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Ana Vanessa Herrero

articles.headline: The Danger From Low-Skilled Immigrants: Not Having Them
articles.snippet: A wealth of research shows that the economy is lifted by foreign workers, providing new opportunities for the native-born.
articles.abstract: A wealth of research shows that the economy is lifted by foreign workers, providing new opportunities for the native-born.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s just say it plainly: The United States needs more low-skilled immigrants.
